# Theory

If there is an effect of departmental prestige on the formation of interuniversity collaboration networks present, then it would also be reflected on the individual level. Sociologists who have a lower h-index could then benefit from the collective prestige of their department. This is called basking in reflective glory, which is a well known effect within the social networks literature.

The **principle of preferential attachment** [@Hancean2014], who quotes [@Moody2004] and someone else). "New links and nodes are not randomly connected to large networks, but based on observed power-law distributions" (page number). Matthew-effect: scientific fields grow and develop around highly prestigious scientific scholars. These highly prestigious scholars are star nodes (source).

A prestigious ego receives more ties than they send themselves [@Knoke2011].

H1. Sociologists prefer working with a sociologist with a higher individual prestige than themselves
H2. Sociologists prefer working with a sociologist with a higher departmental prestige than themselves
